There is no high quality evidence that MVA is as safe as D & C, and there is no evidence that the higher-quality MVA results are less likely to be affected. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct well-designed trials in this field. There is a case for large randomized trials of high methodological rigour in order to define any differences between MVA and D & C as safe and effective.

There is no evidence of benefit of radiofrequency lumbar sympathectomy compared to phenol lumbar sympathetic neurolysis. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large randomised controlled trials of radiofrequency lumbar sympathectomy in patients with regional pain syndrome type 1.
There is no high quality evidence that penfluridol is effective as a maintenance therapy for schizophrenia. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

We found some limited evidence of effects on smoking behaviour attributable to intervention measures. It is clear from the literature that it is possible to set up the randomised controlled trials or other quasi-experimental designs needed to produce evidence for practice. Qualitative research to explore the relationship between intervention and outcome measures and the use of support materials and programs that might be made more available are needed.

Surgical face masks may be useful for preventing post-operative wound infections. However, there was insufficient evidence from the two studies included in the review to establish the safety or effectiveness of wearing face masks in comparison to no mask or no mask in comparison to no guard or no guard at all. These results should be interpreted cautiously. It is clear from the literature that it is possible to set up the randomised trials or other quasi-experimental designs needed to produce evidence for use of face masks in post-operative care.

We found no clear evidence to support or refute the use of group therapy for children with leukemia. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct well-designed trials in this field. There is a case for large randomized trials of high methodological rigour in order to define any benefit from the use of group therapy for children with leukemia that may be attributed to toxicity.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the effectiveness or ineffectiveness of radio-frequency ablation for the treatment of small hepatocellular carcinoma in patients with cirrhosis. It may be advisable to carry out large randomised clinical trials on this topic.

There is insufficient evidence to evaluate the value of probiotics for the treatment of acute diarrhoea in children. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of probiotics for this purpose, the review authors recommend further research.
There is no evidence to suggest that the oral administration of furosemide reduces the risk of tachypnoea in newborns. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

We found some limited evidence of effects of heparin on long-term outcomes of deep-vein thrombosis in patients with proximal-vein thrombosis but no signs of pulmonary embolism. There was no clear evidence of benefit of enoxaparin compared to unfractionated heparin, and there was a small risk of recurrence of deep-vein thrombosis with treatment of himparin alone. There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of the use of Y-system CAPD systems in reducing the incidence of peritonitis and exit site infection. In view of the modest number of patients studied, methodological shortcomings and poor reporting of the included trials, these results should still be interpreted cautiously. An appropriately powered trial of high methodological rigour is needed to determine if there are patients who may derive benefit from the use of Y-system CAPD.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of misoprostol for induction of labour in women with unfavourable cervix. It may be advisable to carry out this trial in other countries.

There is insufficient evidence to evaluate the value of isokinetic exercise for patients with bilateral knee osteoarthritis (OA). It may be advisable to carry out large randomised clinical trials on this topic.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of fluticasone propionate for patients with mild to moderate asthma. In the absence of evidence to support more intensive use of fluticasone propionate, this treatment should be restricted to patients with moderate to severe asthma. Patients with mild to moderate asthma should be offered entry into a clinical trial.

There is no convincing evidence to support the use of aromatherapy for the treatment of agitated behaviours in people with dementia. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large-scale trials of aromatherapy for dementia.

There is no evidence of cognitive benefit from D-cycloserine in patients with Alzheimer's disease. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large randomised clinical trials of this type in order to define any benefit from D-cycloserine in patients with Alzheimer's disease.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of cognitive behaviour therapy for sleep-maintenance insomnia. In the absence of evidence from randomised controlled trials, we recommend the use of cognitive behaviour therapy for sleep-maintenance insomnia. It is more effective than cognitive behaviour therapy for reducing time awake after sleep onset, and it is more effective than pharmacotherapy for reducing daytime sleepiness. However, there is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of cognitive behaviour therapy for sleep-maintenance insomnia.

We found no clear evidence to support the use of doxorubicin as an adjuvant therapy for endometrial cancer in patients with stage III or IV endometrial cancer with no residual tumour and a low risk of recurrence. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large randomised clinical trials of high methodological quality in order to define the effectiveness of doxorubicin as an adjuvant therapy for endometrial cancer.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the effectiveness or ineffectiveness of amitriptyline as a treatment for depression. In patients with depression where clinicians feel it is safe not to prescribe amitriptyline, it is possible that the drug may be considered as a adjunct to antidepressants. However, this decision should be preceded by conducting randomized controlled trials in these patients.

There was no significant difference in iodine concentration or level of iodine excretion between groups or across studies. The previous version of this review showed that exercise training improved muscle strength in the short term in patients with chronic renal failure when compared to usual care. This updated review provides evidence that in a similar population of patients, exercise training may have similar beneficial effects to existing treatment programs.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of delayed cord clamping in the situation described in this review. It may be advisable to carry out large randomised controlled trials on this topic.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of ampicillin and gentamicin in the treatment of intra-amniotic infection during labour. In the absence of evidence to support the use of any specific type of antibiotic in this situation, women with intra-amniotic infection should be offered entry into a clinical trial. The aim of the trial was to establish the effectiveness of ampicillin and gentamicin in the treatment of intra-amniotic infection during labour and to define the optimal dose and frequency of administration of these drugs.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of prophylactic antibiotics for prevention of post-surgery bacteriuria. In the absence of evidence to support other lines of treatment, this review was unable to recommend a specific type of antibiotic treatment. The review identified six new studies, most of them reporting on interventions not included in the original version. However, the conclusions of the review did not change.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of topiramate for patients with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large-scale trials of this type of treatment in order to define the optimal dose and frequency of administration of topiramate and to examine the safety and effectiveness of this treatment.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of any regimens for women using oral contraceptive methods. These regimens do not demonstrate a reduction in side effects from oral contraceptive methods. However, it is clear from the literature that it is possible to set up the randomised trials or other quasi-experimental designs needed to produce evidence for practice.

There is no high quality evidence that a cognitive-behavioral therapy designed to make smoking cessation more effective is effective for adolescents. There is a limited evidence that a cognitive-behavioral therapy designed to make smoking cessation more effective is effective for adolescents. There is no evidence that a cognitive-behavioral therapy designed to make smoking cessation more effective is effective for adolescents.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of isotretinoin in the treatment of CIN II/III in women with HIV-positive cervical dysplasia. In the absence of evidence to support the use of any specific retinoid in this treatment, these data should be interpreted with caution. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to determine the effectiveness of isotretinoin in the treatment of CIN 2/3 in women with HIV-positive cervical dysplasia.

We found no clear evidence to support the use of any specific type of prism for reading in people with age-related macular degeneration. The use of a specific type of prism for reading in people with age-related macular degeneration is possible, although the evidence is not significant.
There is no convincing evidence to support the use of any specific feeding method for infants with unilateral cleft lip and palate. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.
There is no high quality evidence that acupuncture increases functional ability in patients with acute stroke, and further research is needed.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the effect of PITC on HIV/AIDS prevention in rural Tanzania. It is possible that the small number of participants in this review may have affected the effectiveness of the intervention. Further research is needed to determine the effectiveness of this intervention in different population groups, and to determine whether it has a benefit on HIV/AIDS prevention in rural Tanzania.

There is no convincing evidence to support the use of any specific type of local anaesthetic for the manipulation of distal radius fractures of the distal radius in adults. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of topiramate for the treatment of bipolar disorder. It may be advisable to carry out large randomised clinical trials on this topic.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of cognitive restructuring for posttraumatic stress disorder in women with PTSD. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of cognitive restructuring for posttraumatic stress disorder, it is not possible to recommend a specific intervention. However, it is quite possible to use cognitive restructuring in the treatment of PTSD in women with PTSD.
There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of folic acid for treating depression in adults with dementia. It may be useful in treating patients with mild to moderate dementia.

There is evidence from one trial that combined spinal-epidural analgesia provides a more effective analgesia than epidural analgesia alone. This review provides evidence that in the absence of evidence that combined spinal-epidural analgesia is more effective than epidural analgesia, and that the risk of side-effects is less. There is no definitive evidence that combined spinal-epidural analgesia is more effective than epidural analgesia alone. There is a risk of side-effects with the use of combined spinal-epidural analgesia, which may be reasons for limiting the use of this technique in labour.

There is no high quality evidence that laparoscopic colon resection is effective for stage II or III colon cancer, and there is limited evidence that it is effective for stage III colon cancer. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.
There is no convincing evidence to support the use of any interventions for preventing youth smoking. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the effectiveness of early treatment of Class II malocclusion by bionator, bionator and headgear appliances. The results suggest that early treatment may reduce the incidence of overjet, which may have implications for the outcome of treatment and may be useful in reducing the incidence of tooth loss. However, there is no evidence to support the use of any appliances for Class II malocclusion at a early stage. Olanzapine appears to be beneficial for patients with dementia-related psychosis. However, there is insufficient information about other outcomes and side-effects hence it is difficult to be confident about the trade-offs for these benefits. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality in order to determine the optimal dose and frequency of use of olanzapine in this treatment of dementia.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine feeding of nasojejunal to preterm infants. In the absence of evidence to support more invasive or more technically difficult methods of nasojejunal feeding, the review authors recommend the least invasive and simplest method available. Further randomised trials are warranted, preferably multi-centred trials. The classification of a preterm infant as low birth weight and of high birth weight infants does not seem to be relevant to the clinical care of such infants.

We found a small number of studies that showed a suppression of polydipsia in patients with schizophrenia with the use of naloxone, a opioid antagonist. However, there was insufficient evidence for or against the use of naloxone in the treatment of PIP syndrome. The evidence was not significant for or against other opioid antagonists in the treatment of PIP syndrome.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of quetiapine for the treatment of sexual dysfunction in patients with schizophrenia. In view of the modest number of participants, methodological shortcomings and poor reporting of the included trials, these results should still be interpreted cautiously. An appropriately powered trial of high methodological rigour is needed to determine if there are patients who may derive benefit from quetiapine compared to risperidone.

We found no clear evidence to support the use of OXC for children and adolescents with newly-diagnosed epilepsy for either partial or generalized seizures without partial onset. The results suggest that OXC may be a useful add-on treatment for children and adolescents with newly-diagnosed epilepsy.

There is no convincing evidence to support the use of any interventions for reduction of sodium intake in the treatment of mild to moderate hypertension. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of spinal anesthesia for high-risk infants undergoing inguinal herniorrhaphy. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct well-designed trials in this field. There is a case for large randomized trials of high methodological rigour in order to define any benefit from spinal anesthesia for high-risk infants undergoing inguinal herniorrhaphy.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of ibuprofen as a primary treatment for fever in children with febrile illness. In view of the modest number of children studied, methodological shortcomings and poor reporting of the included trials, these results should still be interpreted cautiously. An appropriately powered trial of high methodological rigour is needed to determine the effectiveness of ibuprofen as a primary treatment for fever in children with febrile illness.

Aerobic exercise may be beneficial for children with learning disabilities. The results suggest that there is a beneficial effect of aerobic exercise on self-concept, body-cathexis, and aerobic power in children with learning disabilities.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of different pacing modes in patients with atrial fibrillation or with chronic atrial fibrillation that causes significant bradycardia. These patients may be candidates for large-scale randomized controlled trials of different pacing modes, which would include endpoints that show the effects of different pacing modes on exercise capacity, symptom satisfaction and clinical outcomes.

We found no clear evidence to support the use of any specific type of recombinant human chorionic gonadotropin for induction of final follicular maturation and early luteinization in women undergoing in vitro fertilization ( ICSI). The review identified six eligible studies, most of them reporting on interventions not included in the original version. However, the conclusions of the review did not change.

There is no convincing evidence to support the use of indomethacin for the prevention of patent ductus arteriosus in very-low-birth-weight infants. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

There is insufficient evidence to decide on the effectiveness or ineffectiveness of any specific combination of metaproterenol and ipratropium for the treatment of acute asthma in children. In view of the modest number of patients studied, methodological shortcomings and poor reporting of the included trials, these results should still be interpreted cautiously. The aim of our study was to determine whether the combination of an anticholinergic treatment with a beta 2-adrenergic medication is a more effective treatment for acute asthma attack than the two treatments individually.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of stepwise excavation for caries lesions in primary teeth. The use of a protective layer to protect the pulp from exposure is effective in reducing the risk of pulp exposure in such cases. However, there is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of the technique for caries in primary teeth.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of human insulin as a treatment for type 1 diabetes. In patients with insulin-dependent diabetes, it is possible that the risk of systemic pancreatic insulins and their adverse effects are not adequately examined. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of human insulin as a treatment for type 1 diabetes, this review provides evidence to support the use of human insulin in this manner.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of losartan as a primary treatment for hypertension. In patients with mild to moderate hypertension, losartan may be an alternative to hydrochlorothiazide because of its lack of a significant adverse effects on long-term health status and cardiovascular function. In patients with systemic hypertension, losartan may be an alternative to hydrochlorothiazide because of its lack of a significant adverse effects on long-term health status and cardiovascular function.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of omega-3 PUFAs for cardiovascular health in patients with peripheral vascular disease and, in particular, to assess their effect on blood pressure, platelet reactivity and lipid levels. However, it is clear from the literature that omega-3 PUFAs may have some benefit on cardiovascular health in patients with peripheral vascular disease and, in particular, on blood pressure.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of hormone replacement for bone mineral accretion in preterm infants. The aim of this review was to define the optimal dose and frequency of administration of hormone replacement in this field and to define the optimal dose and frequency of administration of E2 and P.
There is no high quality evidence that a nutritional supplement can improve CRF in children with moderately to severe Crohn's disease. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of salbutamol as a therapy for asthma. In patients with mild to moderate asthma where symptoms are not controlled by antiinflammatory drugs, salbutamol may be an effective long-term treatment. In patients with moderate to severe asthma where symptoms are not controlled by antiinflammatory drugs, salbutamol may be an effective long-term treatment.

We did not find evidence to support the use of any specific type of radiation for the treatment of stage IIIB cervical cancer. However, a single trial has shown a beneficial effect from the use of hydroxyurea in the treatment of stage IIIB cervical cancer. It must be decided whether this can be extrapolated to other types of cancer or whether it is a useful adjunct to current therapy.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of terbutaline as a prevention of preterm labour in women with suspected preterm labour. In the absence of evidence to support more invasive or more technically difficult methods of prevention, these women should be offered entry into a randomised controlled trial.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of oral contraceptives containing ethinylestradiol as a primary contraceptive. When used in combination with other contraceptives, it is possible that the lower dose EE may have adverse effects on long-term contraceptive effectiveness and fertility. Further adequately powered randomised controlled trials should be undertaken in settings where several women are receiving oral contraceptives, and the risk of endometrial and breast cancer is high.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of the use of thymostimulin for patients with metastatic breast cancer while providing evidence to support the use of G-CSF in such patients. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of thymosin alpha1 as a primary therapy in advanced breast cancer, it should be decided whether to carry out large randomised clinical trials on the subject.

There is no evidence of effect of SCS on limb ischaemia in patients with non-reconstructable critical leg ischaemia, and there is limited evidence of the effectiveness of SCS in preventing limb ischaemia. The current evidence base is limited due to the small number of participants in the studies, the heterogeneity of the assessment or the lack of detailed outcome information that prevented the possibility of cumulative analysis for several outcomes. Nevertheless, these data suggest that there may be a benefit of SCS in preventing leg ischaemia in patients with non-reconstructable critical leg ischaemia.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of quinine for the treatment of acute Plasmodium falciparum malaria in children. In view of the modest number of patients studied, methodological shortcomings and poor reporting of the included trials, these results should still be interpreted cautiously. An appropriately powered trial of high methodological rigour is needed to determine the effectiveness and effectiveness of quinine for children with moderate malaria.

We found no clear evidence to support the use of any specific type of irrigant for long-term urethral catheters in people with neurogenic bladder. The current evidence base is limited due to the small number of participants included in the studies, the heterogeneity of the outcome measures or the lack of detailed outcome information that prevented the possibility of cumulative analysis for several outcomes. Nevertheless, it seems desirable to develop adjunct therapies for long-term urethral catheters in people with neurogenic bladder.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of day hospital treatment for patients with acute psychiatric illness. It is more effective than inpatient treatment in terms of clinical outcomes, and may be more effective than randomised controlled trials in improving clinical outcomes. However, there is a risk of bias due to the small number of participants in the studies, and therefore the heterogeneity of the outcomes.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific type of topical ophthalmic anesthesia for the treatment of patients with trigeminal neuralgia. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence from good-quality, contemporary trials is required in order to assess the effectiveness of topical ophthalmic anesthesia for pain in patients with trigeminal neuralgia properly.

Olanzapine appears to be beneficial for the symptoms of mania in that it reduces depressive symptoms and may reduce weight gain. However, there is insufficient information about the long-term effects of olanzapine compared to other mood-stabilizers and no direct evidence comparing olanzapine with lithium or valproate. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality and adequate sizes in order to determine the effectiveness of olanzapine compared to other mood-stabilizers and to define the optimal dose and frequency of administration of olanzapine.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific antidepressant for treatment of dysthymic disorder. Amisulpride, imipramine, and amitriptyline appear to be equally effective for the symptoms of dysthymia. In early onset dysthymia patients, Amisulpride appears to be more effective than imipramine in terms of lower incidence of treatment failure and adverse events than amitriptyline. There is no evidence to suggest that chlorhexidine is effective for prevention of peripartal infection in women undergoing cesarean delivery. There is a risk of pneumonia from the use of chlorhexidine, and there is a risk of sepsis from the use of chlorhexidine. These data do not support the continued use of chlorhexidine for prevention of peripartal infection in women undergoing cesarean delivery.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of aspirin for prevention of colorectal adenomas. In a prospective trial of high methodological quality, we found a significant effect of aspirin on the rate of adenoma recurrence in patients with familial adenomatous polyposis. The beneficial effects of aspirin on the rate of adenoma recurrence were modest compared to drugs such as aspirin or corticosteroids. Further randomised trials are needed to determine the effectiveness of aspirin in preventing colorectal adenomas and the optimal doses and frequency of administration of aspirin.
There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of G-CSF for children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. It may be advisable to carry out large randomised clinical trials on this topic.
There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of psychotherapy for opioid dependence in primary care patients. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

Interlocks are effective in reducing recidivism among first and second-time DUI offenders, but there is insufficient evidence to support or not support the use of interlocks in overall reduction of recidivism. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality to determine whether interlocks are effective in reducing recidivism among first and second-time DUI offenders.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the effectiveness of the use of telephone consultations for primary healthcare in reducing the use of primary healthcare services for fall- in-patient treatment of stroke, and improving patient satisfaction. However, it is clear from the literature that it is possible to set up the use of telephone consultations for primary health care in a way that would make it more effective.

We found no clear evidence from the trials on the use of penicillamine for patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis is not associated with a beneficial effect on disease progression or overall survival. The evidence from the trials was limited due to the small number of patients included in the studies, the heterogeneity of the assessment or the lack of detailed outcome information that prevented the possibility of cumulative analysis for several outcomes. Nevertheless, this update provides evidence that penicillamine is not associated with a beneficial effect on disease progression or overall survival in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Venous cannulation may be associated with a high rate of pain perception and pain score, which may explain why the use of amethocaine-lidocaine cream is more effective than amethocaine-prilocaine cream in alleviating venous puncture-related pain in children. However, the data on pain perception and pain score were insufficient to make specific recommendations regarding the use of amethocaine-lidocaine cream for venous cannulation in children.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific type of manipulation for mechanical neck pain. In the absence of evidence to support more specific interventions, the review authors recommend the least invasive and simplest technique available. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to determine the effectiveness of this intervention and the optimal dose and frequency of treatment.

The two studies included in this review provide evidence that in the majority of patients with chronic neck pain, the TENS treatment shows a significant improvement in pain, range of motion and disability. In the whiplash syndrome, the TENS treatment appears to be similar to placebo in terms of effectiveness and safety. However, there is no evidence that the pain scores of the TENS groups are similar to placebo or not significantly different. This review does not cover the relative effectiveness of the TENS treatment compared to other treatments, which is at present unclear.

There is no high quality evidence that triflusal is effective for prevention of acute myocardial infarction or non-fatal cerebrovascular events in patients with ischemic stroke or transient ischemic stroke. There is a limited evidence that triflusal is effective for prevention of acute myocardial infarction or non-fatal cerebrovascular events in patients with unstable angina. The evidence base is limited due to the small number of participants in the studies and the heterogeneity of the outcome measures. There is no high quality evidence that folic acid reduces the frequency of seizures and/ or gingival hyperplasia in children with epilepsy but this data are not significant. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of a telephone-based cessation intervention for use of smokeless tobacco in high school boys. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.
Botulinum toxin type B (BoNT/B) is safe and efficacious for the management of patients with type A-resistant cervical dystonia.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific type of hormonal contraceptive for male contraception. The use of any specific type of hormonal contraceptive for male contraception is necessary. In the absence of evidence to support more invasive or more technically difficult methods, the review authors recommend the least invasive and simplest method available, which is to use a small number of small and easily available implants. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to establish the effectiveness of these implants and the optimal doses and regimens and to examine new contraceptive methods.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the quality of life of patients with locally advanced rectal cancer treated for total resection or anterior resection. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of any specific type of surgery for rectal cancer, these patients should be offered entry into a clinical trial.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of safety booster seats in preschools. One study found that the use of booster seats was increased in the intervention communities and that there was a 10% and 25% increase for families with intervention families, respectively. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct well-designed intervention programs in preschools that provide parents with information about the effectiveness of safety booster seats, and to conduct well-designed intervention programs that are both safe and effective.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the effectiveness of different types of HIV care offered to people with HIV in different countries. Implementation should be distinguished from practice, and care should be offered to those who are most in need of care.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of any specific type of catheter for post-operative urinary drainage in women undergoing radical hysterectomy or transurethral prostatectomy. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of any specific type of catheter for post-operative urinary drainage in women undergoing radical hysterectomy or transurethral prostatectomy, clinicians should be encouraged to carry out well-designed trials to confirm or refute existing evidence.

We found no clear evidence regarding the effectiveness of GnRH agonists compared to other gonadotropin releasing hormone agonists, and no outright evidence comparing GnRH agonists with other gonadotropin releasing hormone agonists. The current evidence base is limited due to the small number of participants in the studies, the heterogeneity of the assessment or the lack of detailed outcome information that prevented the possibility of cumulative analysis for several outcomes. Nevertheless it seems desirable to develop GnRH agonists for women with poor response to in vitro fertilization.
There are still too few randomised controlled trials to draw conclusions about the effectiveness of ESPACE, and further research is needed.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific regimens for prevention of relapse of vivax malaria in patients with acute Plasmodium vivax malaria. The current evidence base is limited due to the small number of patients included in the studies, the heterogeneity of the regimens or the lack of detailed outcome information that prevented the possibility of cumulative analysis for several outcomes. Nevertheless it seems desirable to develop regimens for prevention of relapse of vivax malaria in patients with acute Plasmodium vivax malaria that are not overly stratified.

There is no evidence to suggest that involuntary outpatient commitment reduces hospital admissions or length of hospital stay in people with schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of NHD in the treatment of patients with acute myeloid leukemia who are undergoing remission induction. It may be advisable to carry out large randomised clinical trials on this topic.

Current evidence from one trial suggests that cinacalcet may be effective for reducing parathyroid hormone levels and improving calcium and phosphorus levels in patients with secondary hyperparathyroidism. However, the data on Cinacalcet's effects on long-term outcomes and safety are lacking, and further trials are needed.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific type of hyperthermia for treatment of locally advanced cancer of the rectum. In view of the modest number of patients studied, methodological shortcomings and poor reporting of the included trials, these results should still be interpreted cautiously. An appropriately powered trial of high methodological rigour is needed to determine if there is a benefit of hyperthermia for treatment of locally advanced rectal cancer.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the relative effectiveness of I/A-CDP compared to MTX-CF in the treatment of primary osteosarcoma. This review provides evidence that the superior efficacy of I/A-CDP compared to MTX-CF is possible in a small sample size in patients with primary osteosarcoma.
There is no high quality evidence that TENS/Bobath therapy increases muscle strength in the upper limb in stroke patients, and further research is needed.
There is no convincing evidence to support the use of any interventions for children with asthma who are receiving asthma education.

Oxygen supplementation, especially supplemental oxygen, appears to have some small benefits for patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who are unable to exercise themselves. However, most of the studies were done in the 1970s and 1980s and re-evaluation of the strategy of supplemental oxygen in the era of antenatal steroid use and early intervention of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is indicated focusing on administration methods.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the effectiveness of ultrasound-guided sciatic nerve block at the lateral midfemoral level compared to nerve stimulation or no intervention. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of ultrasound for sciatic nerve block in upper limb surgery, this review provides evidence to support or refute the use of any specific type of ultrasound for sciatic nerve block in upper limb surgery.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the effectiveness of computer-based instruction for reducing HIV risk in adolescents. This review provides some evidence to suggest that computer-based instruction may be effective for reducing HIV risk in adolescents. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of any interventions for depression in primary care. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of any interventions for the prevention of ventilator-associated pneumonia in intensive care units. One intervention that may have had a small effect was the introduction of a review and evaluation of the practice of prophylaxis of central venous catheter-associated pneumonia in intensive care units. This review and review of the intervention's effects on incidence and compliance was conducted in settings where prophylaxis was not offered as a choice by the clinicians. However, the findings of the review and review of the intervention's effects on incidence and compliance were significant.

Olanzapine and aripiprazole appear to be similar in effectiveness and safety when used in patients with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder. There is no single clinical sign or symptom that accurately identifies schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder. The evidence produced by this review is limited due to the small number of participants included in the studies, the heterogeneity of the assessment or the lack of detailed outcome information that prevented the possibility of cumulative analysis for several outcomes. Nevertheless it seems desirable to develop adjunct trials to examine the relationship between aripiprazole and other antipsychotics in schizophrenia.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of the use of cefuroxime as a prophylaxis for transrectal prostatic biopsy of the prostate. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of cefuroxime as a prophylaxis for transrectal prostatic biopsy, it is not possible to recommend a specific type of antibiotic prophylaxis. There is insufficient evidence to establish the relative effectiveness of different approaches to radical nephrectomy used in patients with T1 tumors. The current evidence base is limited due to the small number of patients included in the studies, the heterogeneity of the assessment or the lack of detailed outcome information that prevented the possibility of cumulative analysis for several outcomes. Nevertheless it seems desirable to conduct large randomised controlled trials of high methodological rigour in order to define the relative effectiveness of different approaches to radical nephrectomy.
There is no high quality evidence that buffered lidocaine reduces pain or discomfort in patients undergoing catheterisation, and further research is needed.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of different educational strategies for improving completion of treatment of people with latent tuberculosis infection after release from jail. One trial found significant benefit of incentive schemes for completion of therapy in prisons, although the data were not significant for other outcomes. Another trial found significant benefit of incentive schemes for completion of therapy in prisons in developing countries, although the data were not significant for other outcomes.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine transfusion of red blood cells in patients with acute gastrointestinal haemorrhage. However, it is possible that the administration of red blood cells in this manner may have a beneficial effect on systemic hemodynamics. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to determine the effects of blood transfusion on systemic hemodynamics in patients with acute gastrointestinal haemorrhage and on their response to treatment.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of interferon beta-1a for patients with primary progressive multiple sclerosis. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large randomised controlled trials of interferon beta-1a in this field.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific type of drug for the treatment of primary Raynaud's phenomenon. The use of any specific type of drug for the treatment of primary Raynaud's phenomenon is inappropriate.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of palatal closure in patients with submucous cleft palate. In the absence of evidence to support more invasive or more technically difficult methods of closure, these patients should be offered entry into a clinical trial. The low mortality from submucous cleft palate appears to be a relevant basis for the routine administration of palatal closure in this patients.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of heparin for the prevention of pre-eclampsia and/or pregnancy-induced hypertension in women without thrombophilia. However, it is possible that it may be used in this manner in a small sample of women with history of pre-eclampsia. In addition, this review identified women who were undergoing intrauterine ultrasound when they had preeclampsia and who were later found to be at risk of pre-eclampsia. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to confirm the results of this review and to define the optimal dose
There is no convincing evidence to support the use of orthoses for treatment of pain and function in people with RA. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of visual feedback for the treatment of defective sounds or tongue placement in patients with cleft palate. However, it is clear from the literature that the use of visual feedback for tongue placement and frication is effective in the treatment of defective sounds or frication in patients with cleft palate.

Corticosteroids are used for treatment of acute urinary tract infections in children, but evidence from two randomised controlled trials, treating patients with acute lower urinary tract infection without antibiotics, did not show a significant effect. A third trial showed significant benefit of single-dose amoxycillin therapy in patients with acute lower urinary tract infection, although evidence was lacking. Standard amoxycillin therapy is effective in reducing urinary tract infections and improving survival, but there is insufficient evidence for a change in treatment following administration of amoxycillin. There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of Cash and Counseling for people with disabilities. It is clear from the literature that it is possible to set up large-scale randomized controlled trials that would show the effects of Cash and Counseling on health, well-being and quality of life among people with disabilities.

Since the last version of this review, new relevant studies have not provided additional information to change the conclusions. Published literature on the subject lacks the methodological rigour or robust reporting needed to make confident assessments of the role of methotrexate in maintaining remission in patients with Crohn's disease. In view of the modest number of patients studied, methodological shortcomings and poor reporting of the included trials, these results should still be interpreted cautiously. An appropriately powered trial of high methodological rigour is needed to determine if methotrexate is effective in maintaining remission in patients with Crohn's disease.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of CDP571 for patients with moderate to severe Crohn's disease who are not responding to induction therapy. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific type of clomiphene citrate for anovulation in women with anovulation. In view of the modest number of women studied, methodological shortcomings and poor reporting of the included trials, these results should still be interpreted cautiously. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to confirm the conclusions of this review and to define the optimal dose and frequency of administration of clomiphene citrate in an anovulatory women's cycle.
There is no high quality evidence that music therapy reduces anxiety or satisfaction during cesarean delivery, and further research is needed.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists for in vitro fertilization. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists for in vitro fertilization, these studies should be interpreted with caution. The aim of the long-term gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists is to prevent the possibility of a LH surge during ovarian stimulation. There is no high quality evidence that methylprednisolone is effective for acute relapse in multiple sclerosis, and further research is needed.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any interventions for the management of work-related upper-extremity disorders. The review underlines the urgent need to develop effective interventions for the management of work-related upper-extremity disorders.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of prostaglandin E2 for preinduction cervical ripening in patients with unfavourable cervix and in induction of labour. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of prostaglandin E2 for preinduction cervical ripening in patients with unfavorable cervix and in the absence of evidence to support or in favour of induction of labour, women with unfavorable cervix should be offered entry into a clinical trial.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of BTxb in improving clinical outcomes of patients with sialorrhea. This review provides evidence that in a small sample size, there is a statistically significant effect of BTxb on improving clinical outcomes of patients with sialorrhea in comparison to placebo.

We found some limited evidence of effects of glucocorticosteroids on SAR when used alone. However, these data are not large and we recommend further larger studies of high methodological quality before recommendations can be made regarding the use of glucocorticosteroids in SAR.

Although dual blockade of the renin- and angiotensin- II receptor blockers reduces proteinuria and reduces GFR in patients with non-diabetic nephropathy, this results do not apply to patients with chronic kidney disease without ACE inhibitor treatment or with RAS blockade. These results should be interpreted with caution in patients with chronic kidney disease who are already receiving antihypertensive treatment and who are not experiencing any adverse effects from the current blockade. There is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of peritoneal dialysis in the treatment of acute renal failure. Patients with mild to moderate hypercatabolic ARF should be offered entry into a clinical trial of some kind.

This review provides some evidence to show that ciclesonide is more effective than fluticasone propionate in reducing pulmonary complications and in decreasing the incidence of local and systemic adverse effects. In patients with mild to moderate asthma where inhaled corticosteroids are a primary means of treatment, ciclesonide has a similar anti-inflammatory effect to fluticasone without the adverse events. There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of calcium supplementation for prevention of pregnancy-induced hypertension in women with normal pregnancies but high risk of preeclampsia. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of calcium supplementation for prevention of pregnancy-induced hypertension, these trials should be interpreted with caution. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to determine the effectiveness of calcium supplementation for prevention of pregnancy-induced hypertension in women with normal pregnancies and of high risk of preterm labour.

Based on limited evidence, we recommend that patients with occluded central venous access devices be offered entry into a randomised controlled trial for alteplase, that is, that it be offered in a dose that is≥ 2 mg per 2 mL, and that all patients be offered entry into a trial. There is insufficient evidence to evaluate the value of dietary counseling for women with gestational diabetes mellitus in reducing their weight gain and improving their metabolic rate. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of dietary counseling for women with gestational diabetes mellitus, it is advisable to carry out large randomised clinical trials on the topic.

The melanoma outcomes data collected in this review of RCTs of vitamin E and vitamin C supplementation in adults with melanoma and in patients with chronic liver disease are insufficient to support or refute the use of vitamin E and vitamin C in these interventions. There is a need for more RCTs of vitamin E and vitamin C in adults with melanoma and in patients with chronic liver disease.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of FTC-TDF for HIV prevention in men who have sex with men or transgender women. It may be advisable to carry out large randomised clinical trials on this topic.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of early laparoscopic cholecystectomy for patients with acute biliary colic. This review provides evidence that in a small sample size, early cholecystectomy may be a cost-effective treatment for biliary colic.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of ursal pacifiers in the initial days of life. In a multicenter randomized controlled trial of high methodological quality, we found a small reduction in the rate of weaning if mothers are instructed to stop using pacifiers at 3 months. However, this was not statistically significant and there was no evidence to support or not support the use of ursal pacifiers in the initial days of life.

We found a significant effect on disturbed behavior following dronabinol treatment in patients with anorexia and in patients with Alzheimer's disease. This effect was not seen in placebo or placebo-controlled trials and was consistent with the results of one trial. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large randomised clinical trials on the use of dronabinol for treatment of anorexia and in patients with Alzheimer's disease.
There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of edaravone for treating acute ischemic stroke. It may be advisable to carry out large randomised clinical trials on this topic.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of endovaginal ultrasound for the management of threatened preterm labour in women with preterm PROM. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of endovaginal ultrasound for threatened preterm labour, these trials should be interpreted with caution. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to determine the effectiveness of endovaginal ultrasound for threatened preterm labor and the duration of labour.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of bupropion for smoking cessation in people with schizophrenia. In view of the high rate of smoking in this population, and the high quality of the current evidence, it is not possible to arrive at definitive conclusions. This review provides some evidence that in the initial phase of treatment, bupropion may be associated with a lower rate of smoking than placebo or atypical antipsychotic medications. In further trials, bupropion may be associated with a lower rate of smoking than placebo or atypical antipsychotic medications.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the routine practice of performing early tracheostomy in patients with respiratory infections or in patients with trauma who are ventilator-dependent. It may be advisable to carry out this procedure in a small number of patients who are most likely to experience complications.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific type of monoclonal antibody for treatment of ovarian cancer. There is a need for more trials of high methodological quality.
There is no high quality evidence that paroxetine is effective for treating major depressive disorder in people with multiple sclerosis, and further research is needed.

There is no high quality evidence that vigabatrin reduces the frequency of seizures in patients with severe partial epilepsy, and there is limited evidence that the drug reduces the incidence of drowsiness or other adverse effects. These results are not limited to patients with severe epilepsy, and further research is needed to determine if the drug is effective in preventing these seizures and, if so, what sort of benefit it may have.
There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of epoetin alfa for treating anemia in patients with cancer, and further research is needed.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of naftopidil for patients with lower urinary tract symptoms associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of naftopidil for these patients, these data should be interpreted with caution. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to determine the effectiveness of naftopidil for these patients and the optimal dose and frequency of administration.

There is no evidence of effect of magnesium sulfate therapy on outcomes of preeclampsia in comparison to either antepartum or postpartum magnesium sulfate therapy. There is a risk of seizures with the use of MgSO4, but these results are not significant.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the effectiveness or ineffectiveness of diflunisal as a analgesic in postoperative pain. In comparisons with placebo, diflunisal showed a statistically significant advantage for pain management in the first 4 hours but was not significantly more effective than aspirin or zomepirac in the following hours. The evidence to date may justify the development and evaluation of diflunisal as a analgesic in postoperative pain.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of isosorbide mononitrate for induction of cervical ripening in women undergoing surgical termination of pregnancy in the first trimester. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the routine administration of methylphenidate in patients with Bell's palsy. When used as a primary treatment for facial paralysis, the treatment has the potential to enhance quality of life and prevent other adverse effects.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific drug for prevention of blood transfusion reactions in patients with leukemia or bone marrow transplant. Patients with these conditions are more likely to experience a febrile or allergic transfusion reaction, which may explain why there is limited evidence to support the use of any specific drug for prevention of blood transfusion reactions.
There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of S(+)-ibuprofen for pain management in acute surgery. It may be useful for treating chronic pain following surgery.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia in patients undergoing surgery for hip arthroplasty. It is possible that the risk of HIT is attributable to the different definitions of HIT used in different clinical trials. The evidence produced by this review is limited due to the small number of patients included in the studies, the heterogeneity of the assessment or the lack of detailed outcome information that prevented the possibility of cumulative analysis for several outcomes. Nevertheless it seems desirable to develop better definitions of HIT in order to allow better comparisons between patients.

Although polyethylene glycol (PEG) and lactulose (Lactulose) are effective in the treatment of chronic constipation in children, there is insufficient evidence to support their use as maintenance therapy. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to determine the effectiveness of these two drugs in treating chronic constipation.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of external-beam pelvic irradiation in patients with stage Ib cervical cancer. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large randomised clinical trials of this type in order to define the effectiveness of this therapy and to define the optimal dose and frequency of use of external-beam pelvic irradiation in this treatment.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of platinum-containing regimens for ovarian germ-cell tumours in women with MOGCT. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence from good-quality, contemporary trials is required in order to assess the effectiveness of these regimens compared to other regimens and to define the optimal regimens for women with MOGCT.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of fluoride tablets for children with high caries risk. In view of the modest number of participants in the study, methodological shortcomings and poor reporting of the included trials, these results should still be interpreted cautiously. An appropriately powered trial of high methodological rigour is needed to determine if there are children who may derive benefit from the use of fluoride tablets for caries prevention.

There is no evidence of effect of psychological treatment on functional ability in people with hip fracture, and there is limited evidence of the effectiveness of any interventions on mental function. The evidence to date may justify the development and evaluation of programs incorporating psychosocial interventions in the treatment of hip fracture.

We found some limited evidence of effects on postoperative aspartate transferase and glutathione-S-transferase activity attributable to ischemic preconditioning. These results do not apply to absence of ischemic preconditioning or to the lack of IP in the initial stage of hepatectomy. However, it is clear from the literature that the prevention of ischemia-reperfusion injury by preventing the use of ischemic preconditioning is important for a successful liver resection.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of IP/SC in reducing blood loss and ischemic injury during liver resection. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of IP/SC in reducing blood loss and ischemic injury in major liver resections, these patients should be offered entry into a clinical trial.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of multimodal optimization for postoperative recovery in patients undergoing elective colonic resection. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of multimodal optimization in postoperative recovery, it is safe to recommend it. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to determine the effectiveness of multimodal optimization for postoperative recovery and, in particular, to determine which protocols are most effective and which are not. The aim of these trials is to gather data to inform practice.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of "Eat Well with CF" for adults with cystic fibrosis. It may be useful for older adults to learn about the benefits of nutrition education in order to support their decision- making regarding CF-related diet.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of CDP870 for patients with RA compared to other treatments, such as methotrexate or CDP870, but the data suggest a beneficial effect from CDP870 in RA compared to either methotrexate or CDP870, and that the beneficial effects are consistent with each regimens. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to confirm the results of this study and to define the optimal dose and frequency of administration of CDP870 in RA.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of furosemide-reserpine in the treatment of patients with essential hypertension. When used as a primary treatment, it may be advisable to use this drug in conjunction with oral antiepileptics.

There is no convincing evidence to support the use of phenytoin for the treatment of impulsive aggression in people with schizophrenia. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of any interventions for weight loss in primary care. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of Artisan lens implantation compared to LASIK or to any other refractive surgical procedure for myopia. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct well-designed trials in this field.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of vitamin E supplementation for patients with chronic hepatitis C. The aim of this review was to provide evidence for the use of vitamin E in the treatment of chronic hepatitis C. There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of vitamin E in the treatment of patients with chronic hepatitis C.

There is no high quality evidence that baclofen is effective in maintenance treatment of opioid dependence. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large randomised controlled trials of high methodological rigour in this field.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of quetiapine for patients with schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder or schizophrenia who are hospitalised with acute exacerbation of schizophrenia. There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of treadmill training for people with early Parkinson's disease. In view of the modest number of participants, methodological shortcomings and poor reporting of the included trials, these results should still be interpreted cautiously. The aim of treadmill training in early Parkinson's disease is to improve functional ability.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of iron supplementation to patients with chronic kidney disease not on dialysis. In the absence of evidence to support the routine administration of iron supplementation to patients with chronic kidney disease not on dialysis, these patients should be offered entry into a randomised controlled trial.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the effectiveness of arch wires for initial alignment of dental arches. They can be used in conjunction with other aligning materials to produce a more effective and effective solution. The results of this review should be interpreted with caution until further corroborative evidence is established.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of rFVIIa in the treatment of patients with TBI/polytrauma. It is possible that the beneficial effects of rFVIIa may be limited by the small number of participants included in the study, the small number of participants receiving rFVIIa, the small number of participants receiving baseline rFVIIa, or the lack of detailed outcome information that prevented the possibility of cumulative analysis for several outcomes. The aim of this review was to define the optimal dose and frequency of administration of rFVIIa in the treatment of patients with TBI/polytrauma.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of the use of a vein collar for PTFE bypass in femoro-infrapopliteal bypass or for any other type of bypass graft in ischaemia. The use of a vein collar may be useful for preventing the use of PCI in these cases, but there is insufficient evidence to support or not support the use of a vein collar for these purposes. Further randomised trials are needed to confirm the results of this review and to define the optimal use of a vein collar for PTFE bypass in ischaemia.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of psychostimulant treatment for depression in primary care. In most comparisons, the participants were not given more than a few doses of psychostimulant and were not shown to be at risk of serious adverse effects. However, a small number of patients were found to be highly responsive to psychostimulant treatment, with little to no side effects. The evidence to date may justify the development and evaluation of psychostimulant treatment in primary care.

There is insufficient evidence to support the effectiveness of gabapentin for the treatment of tinnitus. In a review of studies including this one, authors of the review found no evidence of a significant effect of gabapentin for tinnitus. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of a home-based intervention to improve the health and safety of parents with intellectual disability. It is clear from the literature that the intervention is effective and that it improves parents' health and safety behaviours.

There is no high quality evidence that desipramine reduces the severity of tic disorders and ADHD in children and adolescents with Tourette's syndrome and ADHD, and there is limited evidence that the drug reduces the severity of Tourette's syndrome and ADHD in adults. There is insufficient evidence to evaluate the value of lycopene for preventing prostate cancer in men with high-grade prostate hyperplasia. In view of the modest number of participants in this study, methodological shortcomings and poor reporting of the included trials, these results should still be interpreted cautiously. An appropriately powered trial of high methodological rigour is needed to determine the effectiveness of lycopene for preventing prostate cancer in men with high-grade prostate hyperplasia.

We found no clear evidence to support the use of fluphenazine for maintenance treatment of schizophrenia. In the absence of evidence to support the use of fluphenazine for maintenance treatment of schizophrenia, this review underlines the urgent need to conduct well-designed trials in this field. There is a case for large randomized trials of high methodological rigour in order to define the effectiveness of maintenance treatment of schizophrenia.

There is insufficient evidence to evaluate the value of oral beta-carotene supplementation for patients with CF compared to placebo, or to examine the effect of supplementation with higher dose Zn compared to placebo. These data do not support the continued use of antibiotics in patients with CF, but do not exclude the possible usefulness of vitamin D supplementation in such patients.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of human papillomavirus (HPV) testing for cervical cancer screening. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of human papillomavirus (HPV) testing for cervical cancer screening, clinicians should continue to use cytological testing for high-risk cervical cancer lesions.

There is no high quality evidence that cyclophosphamide/ methylprednisolone combined treatment reduces the mortality and/or severity of paraquat poisoning in patients with moderate to severe poisoning. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large randomised controlled trials of this type in order to define the effectiveness of this treatment and to define the optimal dose and frequency of administration of this treatment.

However, there is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of artemisinin as a primary treatment for falciparum malaria. A single trial has shown a beneficial effect from the use of spironolactone in the treatment of essential hypertension in a small sample size. It must be decided whether this can be extrapolated to other patients.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of postoperative positioning for small idiopathic macular hole surgery. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large randomised controlled trials of high methodological rigour in this field.

There is no high quality evidence that macrolide improves nasal inspiratory flow, saccharine transit time, olfactory function, or lavage levels in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis, and further research is needed.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of computer-based colonoscopy simulator training for gastroenterology fellows. It may be possible to use this technology to improve the quality of endoscopy training for residents. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

There is no convincing evidence to support the use of any specific type of breathing exercise for people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). In the absence of evidence to support more specific types of breathing exercise, this review was unable to recommend a specific type of exercise.
There is insufficient evidence to establish the effectiveness of the SEE program as a means of improving compliance with antiepileptic drug therapy, and further research is needed.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of naltrexone for the treatment of pruritus of primary biliary cirrhosis. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of total disc replacement for patients with chronic low back pain. It may be advisable to carry out large randomised controlled trials on this topic.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the effectiveness of community-based exercise programs for reducing risk of cardiovascular disease and improving health-related behaviour in people with high risk of cardiovascular disease and cardiovascular disease. Implementation should proceed with caution and activities should be more carefully designed before implementation. In addition to basing intervention design more on theory, there is a large literature discussing experiences with these programs that can be used to draw out a number of lessons that can be learned and that could be used to influence or modify the design of community-based exercise programs.

We found no evidence of benefit from simvastatin compared to either atorvastatin alone or to interferon beta-1a, and some evidence of harm from the combination of these drugs. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large randomised clinical trials of statins in multiple sclerosis.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific type of preoperative ibuprofen for pain management in patients undergoing primary tooth extraction. However, it may be advisable to carry out large randomised clinical trials on the use of preoperative ibuprofen for pain management in patients undergoing primary tooth extraction.

We found no evidence for analgesic effects of sucrose on pain responses in infants during immunization, although it was possible that this could be because of the lack of a non-nutritive taste that would have been associated with higher pain scores. The current evidence suggests that in the absence of non-nutritive sucking, sucrose may have an analgesic effect during immunization.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of early ischemic stroke unit care for improvement in the rate of recoveries of patients with acute ischemic stroke. It may be advisable to carry out large randomised controlled trials on the use of early ischemic stroke unit care for improvement in the rate of recovery of patients with acute ischemic stroke.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of mild hypothermia as a therapy for acute aneurysm clipping in patients with aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large-scale randomised controlled trials of hypothermia in an aneurysm surgery to determine if it is safe and effective.

We found a limited evidence of effect of baclofen on the management of AWS. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large randomised controlled trials of high methodological rigour in the management of AWS.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of sargramostim for patients with active Crohn's disease. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large randomised clinical trials of this type in order to define the effectiveness of sargramostim for patients with active Crohn's disease.

We found some limited evidence to suggest that heparin may be an efficacious adjunct to heparin in the treatment of acute leukaemia. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large randomised clinical trials of heparin in this field.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of the use of any decision aids for informing the practice of antithrombotic therapy in patients with atrial fibrillation. The use of any decision aid for informing the practice of antithrombotic therapy in patients with atrial fibrillation is safe but there is a risk of bias.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of any specific regimens for the care of the umbilical cord in neonates. In the absence of evidence to support or refute any specific regimens for the care of the umbilical cord in preterm infants, it is advisable to carry out large randomised clinical trials on the regimens used in this review.

We found a diversity of criteria that made it difficult to make comparisons across studies. The use of 11 criteria for roentgenogram use in primary care is not effective due to the high number of false-positive findings, the small number of participants and the poor quality of the trials. Further studies are needed to determine if the use of 11 criteria for roentgenogram use is effective and if not, why it is not and the rationale for its use.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of dobutamine stress echocardiography for risk assessment of renal transplantation in type 2 diabetes mellitus or in patients with end-stage renal disease. However, it is possible that it may be useful in the assessment of renal transplantation in these patients. In view of the modest number of patients studied, methodological shortcomings and poor reporting of the included trials, these results should still be interpreted cautiously.
