There is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of fluconazole for the prevention of vaginal candidiasis in women with HIV. In the absence of evidence to support more than one regimen, the review authors recommend the use of only one regimen. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to confirm the results of this review and to define the optimal dose and frequency of administration of fluconazole in this setting.

There is no convincing evidence to support the use of any contraceptive methods for women after abortion, and the evidence is limited due to the small number of women included in the studies, the heterogeneity of the assessment or the lack of detailed information about the methods used. However, it seems desirable to develop adjunct contraceptive methods that might make it easier to use family planning services in post-abortion periods. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality to determine the effectiveness of different contraceptive methods in different population groups and settings.

Internal pancreatic duct stenting is effective in reducing the incidence of pancreatic fistula and in reducing the incidence of hospital stay and mortality in patients with pancreaticoduodenectomy. However, there is insufficient evidence to support the use of external stent in reducing the incidence of pancreatic fistula and in decreasing the incidence of hospital stay and mortality in patients with pancreaticoduodenectomy. However, there is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of interferon beta-1a for patients with RRMS. It may be advisable to carry out large randomised clinical trials on this topic. There is a case for large randomized clinical trials of high methodological rigour in order to define any benefit from the use of interferon beta-1a in RRMS.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of radial head replacement with polylactide pins compared to standard metal implants or with no prosthesis at all. The results suggest that the risk of postoperative complications is less with polylactide pins compared to standard metal implants or with no prosthesis at all. The quality and quantity of clinical outcomes of radial head replacement with polylactide pins are comparable to or better than with no prosthesis or with no prosthesis at all.

There is no high quality evidence that bupropion is effective in improving smoking cessation rates in indigenous people, and this review underlines the urgent need to conduct large-scale studies of this type.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of cryosurgery for the treatment of metastatic liver metastases.

There are still only a small number of studies assessing the use of hypnosis for labour and childbirth. Although the intervention shows some promise, further research is needed before recommendations can be made regarding its clinical usefulness for pain management in maternity care.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of sterile water to women in labour for pain relief. In the absence of evidence to support more invasive or more technically difficult methods of treatment, this review has been limited by the small number of women included in the study, the heterogeneity of the assessment or the lack of detailed outcome information that prevented the possibility of cumulative analysis for several outcomes. Nevertheless it seems desirable to develop adjunct sterile water injections that might provide more information about the benefit of sterile water for pain relief in labour and, in particular, about the optimal dose and frequency of the injections.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of cognitive training for people with multiple sclerosis (MS) because the data are scarce and the outcomes are not always significant. However, the current evidence suggests that cognitive training may be useful for people with MS who are experiencing fatigue, cognitive function and quality of life issues.
We found some limited evidence of effects on adherence attributable to telephone-based psychotherapy, but these results were not statistically significant and further research is needed.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of a Move to Improve-type intervention for increase in physical activity in male shift workers. It may be advisable to carry out large randomised controlled trials on this topic.

There is no evidence of effect of aromatherapy on pain perception, length of labour or NICU stay in women undergoing labour. This review does not cover the relative effectiveness of aromatherapy compared with standard care, which is at present unclear. There is no clear evidence of benefit of aromatherapy on long-term outcomes such as neonatal wellbeing.

We found a small number of studies that showed beneficial effects of non-pharmacological interventions on blood pressure in people with high-normal blood pressure. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large-scale trials of high methodological rigour in this field.

There is no convincing evidence to support the use of any interventions for postoperative pain management in NHS maternity care. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.
There is no convincing evidence to support the use of high-dose chemotherapy with BEAM for patients with relapsed Hodgkin's disease. There is a need for more studies of high methodological quality.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of this intervention for pregnant women with intimate partner violence. It may be advisable to carry out large randomised controlled trials on this topic.

There is no high quality evidence that allopurinol is effective for patients with advanced colonic cancer, and a multicenter randomized controlled trial using the radical scavengers DMSO and allopurinol was found to be beneficial. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large randomized controlled trials of radical scavengers in advanced colonic cancer.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine administration of bevacizumab in the treatment of macular edema after BRVO. In patients with cystoid macular edema secondary to non-ischemic branch retinal vein occlusion, bevacizumab may be a useful adjunct to intraocular injections. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to confirm the results of this review and to define the optimal dose and frequency of administration of bevacizumab.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the value of swimming for children with asthma. In view of the modest number of participants, methodological shortcomings and poor reporting of the included trials, these results should still be interpreted cautiously. An appropriately powered trial of high methodological rigour is needed to determine if swimming has a role for children with asthma in terms of reducing symptoms, improving physical activity and improving quality of life.

There is insufficient evidence to establish the safety or effectiveness of WGC as a cannulation technique in post-ERCP pancreatitis. In comparisons with other methods of cannulation, WGC was associated with a lower incidence of acute pancreatitis, was associated with a lower incidence of post-ERCP pancreatitis, and had a lower incidence of complications than other methods. However, the use of WGC in post-ERCP pancreatitis appeared to be similar to other methods of cannulation, with no significant differences in safety or effectiveness. There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography and endoscopic papillotomy in the treatment of acute biliary pancreatitis. Patients with acute gallstone pancreatitis without obstructive jaundice are eligible for treatment with endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography and endoscopic papillotomy, although the effectiveness and safety of these interventions is unclear. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to establish the effectiveness and safety of early endoscopic intervention in the treatment of acute gallstone pancreatitis and biliopancreatic obstruction.

We found no clear evidence to support the use of teriflunomide for patients with RRMS who were already receiving interferon-β therapy, and who had not undergone a relapse. However, this does not exclude the possible usefulness of this therapy for patients with RRMS who were already receiving interferon-β therapy and were awaiting a relapse.

There is insufficient evidence to assess the effectiveness of interventions to integrate family planning and HIV testing into HIV care in Ethiopia. Implementation should proceed with caution and further studies should be undertaken.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of tinzaparin for acute painful crisis of SCA. It should be recognised that, due to the poor quality of the trials, conclusions should be drawn with caution.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of tranexamic acid for hip fracture surgery. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large randomised controlled trials of this type in order to define the effectiveness of this treatment and to define the risk of vascular events.

There is no evidence to suggest that the closed peritoneum is effective in preventing burst abdomen or hernia. In the absence of evidence to support or refute the use of a separate peritoneal suture line for closure of vertical abdominal surgery, we recommend the least invasive and simplest technique available. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to confirm the results of this review and to define the optimal closure technique for abdominal surgery.

We found no clear evidence to support the use of gabapentin for the prophylaxis of migraine. In patients with migraine where a basal rate of 1200 mg is effective, gabapentin reduces the frequency of attacks and may reduce the use of symptomatic drugs. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct large randomised clinical trials of gabapentin for prophylaxis of migraine.
